elements.title: Layered Trust Verification Stack: Substitute Signifiers for Physical Inspection
elements.problem: Susan demands to physically inspect the space three times (2:14, 3:05, 3:42) because the listing's current signifiers are insufficient to replace the affordance of seeing the space in person. The platform enforces a no-preview policy (anti-affordance) for the host's privacy, but this anti-affordance has no discoverable substitute signifier. Susan does not learn about the first-night cancellation guarantee until Bryant improvises it verbally (3:16). She does not see verified photos because none are presented during the call. Her friend is flying from Oregon — the cost of a wrong decision is an airline ticket plus the booking, making the stakes catastrophically high. Norman states: 'To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable — perceivable. If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.' The listing page must structure its trust information so that substitute signifiers for physical inspection are the first things the guest perceives, not supplementary details buried below property features.
elements.solution: Structure the listing page's information hierarchy so that trust verification signifiers occupy the primary visual position, above property features. The hierarchy is: (1) Verified photo gallery with a 'Verified by Split Lease' badge and timestamp — photos must cover the exact elements Susan asked about: room, bathroom (1:08), common areas, building entrance. (2) First-night cancellation guarantee displayed with the same visual prominence as the nightly rate — not in terms and conditions, not in a tooltip, but as a peer-level signifier alongside price. (3) Host identity verification: verified name, photo, response time, and number of prior guests. (4) A brief explanation of the no-preview policy: 'For the host's privacy, tours aren't available before booking. Here is how we verify every listing instead...' This transforms the anti-affordance from a glass wall into a signified constraint with visible alternatives. The pattern is: explain what you prevent, then immediately signify what you provide instead.

evidence.quote: I do have to see the room before she puts her tickets. I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's demand for inspection is a trust requirement rooted in prior scam experiences. Her default conceptual model for remote housing is 'likely fraud until physically verified.' The listing page's information architecture must directly counteract this model with verification signifiers that are perceivable within the first scroll.

evidence.quote: To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable — perceivable. This poses a difficulty with glass... If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.
evidence.insight: The no-preview policy is a glass wall. Susan runs into it three times without understanding why it exists or what alternatives are available. The listing page must signify both the anti-affordance (why no tours) and the substitute affordances (verified photos, cancellation guarantee, host verification).

evidence.quote: There would be something set up where if you come the first night and it's not something that would work, you have the flexibility to cancel.
evidence.insight: Bryant improvises the most critical trust affordance in the entire call — the first-night cancellation guarantee. This affordance is invisible on the platform. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.' This must become a primary signifier, not a hidden policy.

evidence.quote: If I like the room in the bathroom, I can, should have pictures. And she said, it's okay. I'll give you the deposit right there.
evidence.insight: Susan spontaneously identifies photos as the acceptable substitute for physical inspection AND immediately couples photos with readiness to pay. The conversion path is: verified photos seen → trust established → deposit offered. The information architecture must place photos at the top of this causal chain.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: verified photo gallery with verification badge and timestamp (trust evidence that replaces physical inspection). Secondary: first-night cancellation guarantee displayed as a peer signifier to nightly rate (safety net that makes the no-preview policy acceptable). Tertiary: host identity verification card with response metrics and guest count (social proof of legitimacy). The ordering follows Susan's decision sequence: see the space (photos) → know I can leave (cancellation) → know the host is real (verification).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate on listing page load: verified photo gallery with badge, first-night guarantee callout, host identity card. All three are above the fold. On scroll: no-preview policy explanation with link to verification process. On the acceptance screen: cancellation terms restated with one-line summary. At move-in: cancellation guarantee re-signified in the House Manual's first section, with clear instructions on how to exercise it.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 trust signifiers visible simultaneously on the listing page (photos, cancellation badge, host card). Each signifier communicates its message in under 5 words of label text. The no-preview explanation is a maximum of 2 sentences. No legal language in the primary trust layer — legal terms are available on demand but never in the primary scan path.
scan_order: Verified photo gallery with 'Verified' badge (System 1 visual evidence: 'I can see the space', under 2 seconds)
First-night cancellation guarantee badge next to price (System 1 safety signal: 'I can leave if it is wrong', 2-4 seconds)
Host identity card with photo, name, response time (System 1 social proof: 'A real person is behind this', 4-6 seconds)
No-preview policy explanation (System 2, only if the guest wonders why tours are not available, 6+ seconds)
exclude: Trust signifiers buried below property features or amenity lists. Trust must be primary, not supplementary.
Cancellation terms presented only in legal fine print or a separate Terms page. The guarantee must be a visual signifier, not a legal document.
Unverified or host-uploaded-only photos without a platform verification badge. Unverified photos do not counteract Susan's 'run around' mental model.
Host identity displayed as a name-only text link. The host card must include a photo and response metrics to function as a social proof signifier.

elements.title: Platform Identity Signifier: Communicate What Split Lease Is Within One Scan
elements.problem: Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55: 'Real estate Agent'). She does not understand the non-continuous nights model ('Like seven nights a week?' at 0:43) and requires Bryant to explain it three times across the call. Norman's discoverability principle requires that 'it be possible to figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them.' Susan cannot figure out what the service IS, let alone what actions it affords. The platform's core value proposition — schedule-native shared housing where guests book only the nights they need — has no perceivable signifier that a first-time visitor can process without human translation. Norman warns that 'hand-lettered signs pasted on products = poor design' — when you need to explain what something is, the design itself has failed. The landing page and every listing page must carry a signifier that communicates the non-continuous model in the guest's natural vocabulary, not platform jargon.
elements.solution: Every page must carry a persistent identity signifier that communicates Split Lease's model in the guest's vocabulary. The landing page's primary headline must signify the core concept in one sentence using natural language: 'Book the nights you need. Skip the ones you don't.' Not 'non-continuous set of nights.' Not 'periodic tenancy marketplace.' Not 'schedule-native housing platform.' The guest's vocabulary is: nights, weekdays, months, private room. On listing pages, the identity signifier appears as a compact contextual badge: 'Part-time stay: pick your nights' — visible on every listing card and at the top of every listing detail page. In search, the available schedule pattern is the first filter dimension, not buried behind location or price: 'When do you need the space?' with presets for 'Weekdays,' 'Weekends,' 'Full week.' The pattern is: every page answers 'What is this service?' before answering 'What does this listing offer?'

evidence.quote: Real estate Agent.
evidence.insight: Susan's misidentification reveals that the platform communicates nothing about its category or model. Her System 1 defaults to the closest familiar category (real estate brokerage) because Split Lease's actual category has no perceivable signifier. The information architecture must prevent this miscategorization by making the model self-evident.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan's default conceptual model for housing is full-time occupancy. 'Non-continuous set of nights' is platform language that fails as a signifier. The information architecture must use the guest's own vocabulary to communicate the part-time model: 'pick your nights,' 'weekdays only,' 'book 3 nights a week.'

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: Norman's signifier principle applies at the service level, not just the UI level. Before the guest evaluates any listing, they must understand what kind of service they are using. The signifier 'Book the nights you need' communicates both the service model and the primary action in one phrase.

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device. If it is incomplete or contradictory, there will be trouble.
evidence.insight: Split Lease's system image is currently incoherent because no page communicates what the service is independently of a human explanation. The information architecture must establish a coherent system image through consistent, self-explanatory signifiers on every page.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: one-sentence identity signifier using guest vocabulary ('Book the nights you need'). Secondary: schedule pattern context on each listing ('This space is available weeknights' or 'Available 3+ nights/week'). Tertiary: detailed model explanation available on demand ('How does Split Lease work?'). The ordering ensures that the guest understands the SERVICE before evaluating any LISTING.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On landing page: identity signifier as the page's primary headline, visible on load. On listing cards in search results: compact schedule badge showing available pattern. On listing detail page: identity signifier as a contextual subtitle below the listing title. On demand: 'How it works' expandable section with a 3-step explanation using visual examples. The identity signifier is never absent from any page — it is the persistent system image anchor.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Identity signifier: maximum 8 words. Schedule badge on listing cards: maximum 4 words ('Weeknights available' or 'Mon-Fri stays'). The 'How it works' section: maximum 3 steps, each with a single illustration and one sentence. No internal jargon ('non-continuous,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'lease style') in any guest-facing signifier.
scan_order: Identity headline: 'Book the nights you need' (System 1 comprehension: 'I understand what this is', under 2 seconds)
Schedule badge on listing cards: 'Weeknights' or 'Flexible schedule' (System 1 relevance check: 'Does this match my need?', 2-3 seconds)
Listing-specific details: room type, bathroom, location (System 2 evaluation: 'Is this specific space right?', 3-6 seconds)
Service explanation: 'How it works' section (System 2, only if the guest needs more detail, 6+ seconds)
exclude: Platform jargon as user-facing signifiers: 'non-continuous set of nights,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'lease style,' 'schedule-native housing.'
Marketing language that describes the company rather than signifying the model: 'We connect hosts and guests' tells the guest nothing actionable.
Landing pages that lead with property photos before establishing what the service is. The guest must understand the model before evaluating listings.
Any page where the guest must click 'Learn More' or navigate to a separate page to understand the basic service model.

elements.title: Natural-Language Duration Mapping: Calendar Months and Weekday Presets as Primary Input Signifiers
elements.problem: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months,' 0:11), weekday names ('Monday to Friday,' implied at 3:58), and space types ('full apartment or is it a bedroom,' 0:43). The platform requires night counts ('30 night minimum,' 1:35) and individual day toggles. Bryant performs the mapping between Susan's vocabulary and the platform's vocabulary twice during the call (0:19-0:35 and 1:35-2:00). Norman's mapping principle states that 'natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.' When the input controls use the platform's vocabulary (night counts, lease durations), the guest must perform a cognitive translation from their natural vocabulary (months, weekdays) — a System 2 effort that depletes the same resources needed for the actual decision. The proposal creation form's signifiers must use the guest's vocabulary as the primary framing, with the platform's internal units as secondary annotation.
elements.solution: Design every duration and schedule input to speak the guest's language first and the platform's language second. Duration selection: present presets labeled in calendar time — 'About 1 month,' 'About 2 months,' '3+ months' — as the primary input. Show the equivalent night count as a secondary annotation: 'About 2 months (approx. 40 nights at 5 nights/week).' Schedule selection: provide one-tap presets for common patterns — 'Weekdays (Mon-Fri),' 'Weekends (Sat-Sun),' 'Full week,' 'Custom' — as the primary input. The custom option reveals individual day toggles only when the presets do not match. A real-time summary line below the selectors performs the mapping visually: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights, starting [date].' This summary is the digital equivalent of Bryant's verbal translation at 1:35-2:00. The pattern is: accept the guest's vocabulary, translate internally, show both languages simultaneously for transparency.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan defaults to full-time occupancy because her conceptual model has no category for part-time housing. The duration input must not assume the guest already understands the non-continuous model. Presets labeled 'Weekdays' or '3 nights/week' signify the part-time concept through the input control itself.

evidence.quote: Natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding. For example, to move an object up, move the control up.
evidence.insight: A calendar-based duration selector where the guest sees weeks highlighted on a visual calendar is a natural mapping. A number field labeled 'minimum nights' is an arbitrary mapping that requires translation. The input control itself must signify the mapping.

evidence.quote: Rita would require a 30 night minimum... five nights a week for like two months would be something that would, could work.
evidence.insight: Bryant translates Susan's '1-2 months' into the platform's '30 night minimum' in real time. The proposal form must perform this same translation visually. The guest enters their natural-language parameters; the form computes and displays the platform's internal values alongside.

evidence.quote: Do five days a week. And then would there be a preference for those days, like weekdays?... It's Monday to Friday will be better.
evidence.insight: Susan's natural expression for the schedule is 'Monday to Friday.' This must be a one-tap preset, not five individual day toggles. Norman's natural mapping principle: the control must match the guest's mental representation of the action.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: calendar-time presets (months, weekday groups) as the first input the guest sees. Secondary: real-time translation summary showing both guest vocabulary and platform units ('Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights at $X/night = $Y total'). Tertiary: custom input fields for guests whose needs do not match any preset. The ordering ensures the guest never encounters the platform's internal vocabulary before seeing their own.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On search: schedule presets as the first filter dimension ('When do you need the space?' before 'Where?' or 'How much?'). On proposal creation: duration presets appear first, followed by schedule presets, then the real-time summary. Custom inputs are hidden behind a 'Custom schedule' toggle and only revealed on demand. The translation summary updates in real time as the guest modifies any input — this is Norman's immediate feedback principle applied to the mapping display.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 duration presets visible (1 month, 2 months, 3 months, custom). Maximum 4 schedule presets visible (Weekdays, Weekends, Full week, Custom). The real-time summary is a single line, maximum 15 words. No platform-native terms (night count, lease duration, periodic tenancy) appear without a guest-vocabulary equivalent alongside.
scan_order: Schedule presets: 'Weekdays (Mon-Fri)' / 'Weekends' / 'Full week' (System 1: 'Does my pattern match?', under 2 seconds)
Duration presets: 'About 1 month' / '2 months' / '3+ months' (System 1: 'How long do I need?', 2-3 seconds)
Real-time translation summary: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights, $X total' (System 2: 'What does that actually mean?', 3-5 seconds)
Custom input toggle for non-standard schedules (System 2, only if presets do not match, 5+ seconds)
exclude: Night count fields as the primary duration input. Guests think in months, not nights.
Individual day-of-week toggles as the primary schedule input. A 'Weekdays' preset captures Monday-Friday in one tap.
Platform terminology ('30 night minimum,' 'non-continuous set of nights') without a guest-vocabulary translation alongside.

Duration inputs that do not show a real-time cost calculation. Susan's friend is budgeting a cross-country trip; the financial consequence of the duration choice must be visible as the guest configures it.

elements.title: Negotiation Feedback Timeline: Show What Happened, What Is Happening, and What Happens Next
elements.problem: The Susan call contains a complete negotiation micro-cycle: demand (physical inspection, 2:14) → rejection (not allowed, 3:05) → compromise (first-night cancellation, 3:16). At every exchange, Bryant provides immediate verbal feedback — acknowledgment, explanation, counter-proposal. The platform's negotiation flow is asynchronous: the guest submits a proposal, the host considers it offline, and the response arrives hours or days later. Norman states: 'Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up.' The call demonstrates this directly: when the phone connection drops at 2:42-3:05, both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?' — trust erodes within seconds of lost feedback. Every hour a proposal sits in 'pending' without informative status updates is an hour the guest's trust decays. The information architecture must replace the verbal negotiation's continuous feedback with a structured timeline that makes the asynchronous process feel transparent and progressing.
elements.solution: Design the negotiation status as a visual timeline that answers three questions at a glance: What happened? What is happening right now? What happens next? The timeline has discrete states, each with a specific signifier: (1) 'Proposal Sent' — timestamp, summary of terms, confirmation that the host was notified. (2) 'Host Reviewing' — host's typical response time ('Rita usually responds within 6 hours'), last activity indicator. (3) 'Host Responded' — the response (accepted, countered, or declined) with specific details visible immediately. (4) 'Your Turn' — if the host countered, the guest sees what changed and what action they can take. (5) 'Agreed' or 'Expired' — final state. At each state, the timeline shows one line of what happened, one line of what is happening, and one line of what comes next. Intermediate feedback ('still waiting') fires at predictable intervals. The pattern is: no state should ever feel like silence. Every moment in the negotiation must have a visible, informative signifier.

evidence.quote: Can you hear me, Susan? Me? Yep. Can you hear me? No, I, yeah. You're you're back. I can hear you. Can you hear me? Yes. I can hear you.
evidence.insight: A 20-second feedback gap in the phone call causes immediate anxiety and scrambling. This is the analog of a platform showing 'pending' for hours with no status update. The information architecture must prevent this feedback vacuum by signifying progress even when nothing has changed ('Rita has not yet responded. Most hosts respond within 6 hours.').

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up, going off to do other activities.
evidence.insight: For asynchronous negotiations, 'immediate' means instant acknowledgment of the guest's action plus a realistic timeline for the host's response. The guest must never wonder whether their proposal was received. The timeline signifier replaces 'pending' with 'Host Reviewing — typically responds in 6 hours.'

evidence.quote: I'll be in contact with Rita. And like I said, I'll keep you updated.
evidence.insight: Bryant's promise of future feedback is the only 'next steps' signifier Susan receives. The platform must replace human promises with systematic, visible status timelines — a persistent signifier that does not depend on any individual remembering to follow up.

evidence.quote: Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive. Feedback must also be prioritized, so that unimportant information is presented in an unobtrusive fashion, but important signals are presented in a way that does capture attention.
evidence.insight: The negotiation timeline must distinguish between high-priority feedback (host countered your proposal — action required) and low-priority feedback (proposal still being reviewed — no action needed). Both are signified, but with different visual urgency.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current state indicator with one-line description ('Host Reviewing — usually responds in 6 hours'). Secondary: next action signifier ('You will be notified when Rita responds' or 'Your turn: review Rita's counter-proposal'). Tertiary: history of prior states with timestamps ('Proposal sent Feb 17 at 3:42 PM'). The ordering ensures the guest always knows the present state before needing to review the history.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On proposal submission: instant confirmation with timeline visualization showing the current state. While waiting: intermediate feedback at predictable intervals (6 hours, 12 hours, 24 hours) with host response time context. On host response: push notification with the specific response, not a generic 'update available.' On guest's turn: action prompt with the specific terms that changed and a one-tap response option. After agreement: confirmation with move-in date, key terms summary, and next steps.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 timeline states visible at once (previous, current, next). Each state is described in one line of maximum 12 words. The full negotiation history is available on demand but never the default view. Counter-offer changes are highlighted with a visual diff — the guest sees only what changed, not the entire proposal restated.
scan_order: Current state badge: 'Host Reviewing' or 'Your Turn' or 'Agreed' (System 1: 'Where are we?', under 1 second)
Timeline context: 'Rita usually responds in 6 hours' or 'Rita countered: 4 nights/week instead of 5' (System 1/2: 'What is happening?', 1-3 seconds)
Next action: 'You will be notified' or 'Review counter-proposal' button (System 2: 'What do I do?', 3-5 seconds)
History: previous states with timestamps (System 2: 'What happened before?', only on demand)
exclude: A generic 'Pending' state with no timeline or response time context. Every waiting state must signify expected duration.
Identical notification patterns for different events. A counter-offer and a status update must look and feel different.
Negotiation history that requires navigating to a separate page. The timeline is inline, on the same screen as the current state.
Counter-offers presented as full proposal restates. Only the changed terms should be highlighted; unchanged terms are dimmed or collapsed.

elements.title: Proxy Booking Information Structure: Two Roles, Two Information Needs, One Booking Flow
elements.problem: Susan is booking on behalf of a friend from Oregon. She says 'I can give you a deposit on her behalf' (2:34), 'I'm setting up all appointments for her' (3:58-4:31), and 'before she puts her tickets' (2:14). The platform's information architecture assumes a single-user model: the person searching, evaluating, and proposing is the person staying. Norman's conceptual model principle states that 'a conceptual model is an explanation, usually highly simplified, of how something works. It doesn't have to be complete or even accurate as long as it is useful.' The one-guest-one-user model is not useful when proxies are involved. The proxy (Susan) needs information about logistics, payments, and host communication. The occupant (friend) needs information about the space, check-in procedures, and house rules. If the information architecture does not distinguish these two roles, both users receive either too much irrelevant information or miss critical role-specific information. The proxy booking affordance exists (you can fill out forms and pay for someone else), but without a signifier indicating this is possible, Susan would either pretend to be the guest or abandon.
elements.solution: Add a role-selection signifier at the start of the proposal flow: 'Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?' This single toggle restructures the information architecture for the rest of the journey. When 'Booking for someone else' is selected: (1) The proposal form collects two profiles — coordinator (Susan: contact info, payment method, local presence) and occupant (friend: name, arrival date, needs). (2) Confirmation and status updates are sent to both users, but with role-appropriate content: the coordinator receives logistics and payment updates; the occupant receives check-in details and house rules. (3) During the active lease, the Stays Manager shows the coordinator a management view (payment history, upcoming stays, date change tools) and the occupant an operational view (current stay details, House Manual, host contact). (4) The information architecture constrains each role's affordances: the coordinator can pay and reschedule; the occupant can check in, submit cleaning photos, and write reviews. Neither is overwhelmed with the other's information.

evidence.quote: I like to see the place and I can give you a deposit on her behalf and she's ready to come whenever I can find her spot.
evidence.insight: Susan explicitly describes the proxy pattern: she inspects and pays, the friend occupies. The information architecture must capture this split-responsibility model and deliver role-appropriate information to each person.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: If the platform offers no signifier for proxy booking, Susan must either pretend to be the guest (creating incorrect data) or abandon. The role-selection toggle is a signifier that makes the proxy affordance discoverable: 'You can book for someone else, and here is how.'

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her.
evidence.insight: Susan manages logistics remotely while her friend occupies the space locally. The active lease information architecture must support this distributed pattern: one person sees the management view, the other sees the operational view.

evidence.quote: Good conceptual models are the key to understandable, enjoyable products: good communication is the key to good conceptual models.
evidence.insight: The platform's conceptual model must communicate a two-person booking structure clearly. Without distinct signifiers for the coordinator role and the occupant role, both users struggle to understand what actions are available to them and which information is relevant.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: role-selection signifier at the start of the proposal flow ('Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?'). Secondary: role-specific information panels — the coordinator sees payment and scheduling; the occupant sees space details and check-in. Tertiary: shared information (listing details, host profile) available to both roles without duplication. The ordering ensures the system knows which role it is serving before presenting any information.
elements.disclosure_pattern: At proposal start: role-selection toggle, prominent and early in the flow (before any form fields). After role selection: the form restructures to collect coordinator profile and occupant profile sequentially, not simultaneously. During negotiation: status updates go to both users, but the coordinator receives logistics-focused summaries and the occupant receives space-focused summaries. During active lease: the Stays Manager renders a different primary view based on role — management for coordinator, operations for occupant. Both can access the other's view on demand.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The role-selection toggle adds exactly one decision (2 options) to the start of the flow. Each role's profile requires maximum 4 fields (name, contact, relationship, specific needs). The dual-notification system sends maximum 2 messages per event — one per role — each containing maximum 3 data points relevant to that role. No user sees information intended for the other role unless they explicitly request it.
scan_order: Role selection: 'Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?' (System 1: 'This service understands my situation', under 2 seconds)
Coordinator profile: name, contact, payment method (System 2: 'What do you need from me?', 2-5 seconds)
Occupant profile: name, arrival date, special needs (System 2: 'What does my friend need?', 5-8 seconds)
Role-specific information panels during active lease (System 1 on repeat visits: 'Show me what is relevant to my role', under 3 seconds)
exclude: A single-user form that forces the proxy to enter their own name as the guest. This creates incorrect records and a broken conceptual model.
Proxy booking hidden behind account settings or a help article. The signifier must appear at the natural decision point (start of proposal flow), not in a configuration menu.
Identical notifications sent to coordinator and occupant. Each role needs different information; sending everything to everyone creates noise.
A requirement for the occupant to create an account before the coordinator can complete the booking. Susan must be able to book on her friend's behalf without the friend being on the platform.

elements.title: Move-In Knowledge-in-the-World: House Manual as Chronological Action Sequence, Not Topic Reference
elements.problem: Susan's entire call is organized around preventing a catastrophic move-in failure for her friend flying from Oregon. The friend has never been to the space, has no local knowledge, and arrives with only the listing's digital signifiers as her conceptual model of the space. Norman distinguishes between 'knowledge in the head' (what the guest remembers from the listing) and 'knowledge in the world' (what is available in the environment at the moment of action). At move-in, the guest's knowledge in the head is limited and potentially distorted. She needs knowledge in the world: how to enter the building, find the room, use the Wi-Fi, contact the host if something is wrong, and exercise the cancellation guarantee if the space does not match. The House Manual is the primary vehicle for this knowledge, but only if it is organized by the guest's action sequence at arrival, not by topic category. Norman: 'A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly.' A topic-organized manual ('Wi-Fi,' 'Appliances,' 'Neighborhood') forces the guest to search for the right section at each step. A chronological manual ('Step 1: Enter the building,' 'Step 2: Find your room') maps directly to the action sequence.
elements.solution: Structure the House Manual as a chronological move-in sequence that maps to the guest's physical actions on arrival, with the cancellation guarantee as the most prominent element. The sequence is: (1) Access: building entry code, floor, apartment number, key/lockbox location. (2) Verify: a mini-checklist comparing listing claims to physical reality — private bathroom? private room? the bed and kitchen items shown in photos? (3) Connect: Wi-Fi network and password, host contact for immediate issues. (4) Safety net: first-night cancellation guarantee terms and how to exercise them — this is the most important signifier at move-in because it is the safety mechanism that made the booking possible. (5) Settle: house rules, shared space protocols, quiet hours, laundry, trash. (6) Explore: neighborhood basics, transit, grocery. Each section is expandable, one screen per step, with the current step always visible. Co-occupancy status is disclosed at Step 2 ('You may encounter Rita in common areas on weekends') because Susan specifically asked 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20).

evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's anxiety is about the gap between listing claims and physical reality. The move-in verification checklist (Step 2) directly addresses this: it gives the guest a structured way to confirm the space matches the listing, transforming anxiety into actionable verification.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: At move-in, the guest must discover how to enter, verify, connect, and contact — all without prior physical experience. A chronological House Manual makes each action discoverable in the sequence the guest needs it, not in the sequence a content organizer categorized it.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Co-occupancy is a critical move-in variable that Susan surfaced in the evaluation call. If the guest discovers unexpected co-occupants at arrival, every prior trust signifier is invalidated. Co-occupancy status must be disclosed before arrival and re-confirmed in the House Manual's verification step.

evidence.quote: A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly; we do operations as we were told to do them; we can't fully appreciate why, what effects to expect, or what to do if things go wrong.
evidence.insight: The House Manual is the guest's conceptual model of the space and its rules. Norman's principle dictates that it must enable the guest to predict what happens at each step and know what to do if something goes wrong. The chronological structure does this by pairing each action with its expected outcome and its fallback.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current step in the move-in sequence (access instructions on arrival, verification checklist on entry, Wi-Fi on settling). Secondary: cancellation guarantee — always visible as a persistent footer or banner during the first 24 hours, regardless of which step the guest is viewing. Tertiary: house rules and neighborhood details, available once the guest has completed access and verification. The ordering mirrors the guest's temporal needs: get in → check it → connect → know your rights → settle.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Pre-arrival (24 hours before): push notification with access instructions only (Step 1). No other details — reduce cognitive load to one action. On arrival: House Manual opens to Step 1 (access), with Steps 2-6 visible as a collapsed sequence below. After entering: Step 2 (verification checklist) expands automatically. Cancellation guarantee is a persistent banner during the first 24 hours. After first night: banner transitions from cancellation guarantee to house rules summary (Step 5). During active lease: House Manual shifts to reference mode (searchable by topic) after the first week, since the chronological sequence is no longer needed.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 step visible in detail at a time. Each step contains maximum 4 data points (e.g., Step 1: building address, entry code, floor number, door/lockbox description). The verification checklist (Step 2) has maximum 5 items matching the listing's primary claims. The cancellation guarantee summary is maximum 2 sentences. Total House Manual: 6 steps, never more than one screen of content per step.
scan_order: Current action step: building access code or verification item (System 1: 'What do I do right now?', under 2 seconds)
Cancellation guarantee banner: 'Not what you expected? You can cancel within 24 hours' (System 1 safety: 'I have an exit', 2-3 seconds)
Next step preview: collapsed title of the following step (System 1: 'What comes after this?', 3-4 seconds)
Host contact: quick-access button for immediate issues (System 2: 'How do I get help?', 4-5 seconds)
exclude: Topic-organized manual sections ('Wi-Fi,' 'Appliances,' 'Neighborhood') as the default structure. Chronological action sequence is the default; topic search is a secondary mode available after the first week.
Cancellation terms buried in a separate legal page or terms document. The guarantee must be a visual signifier at move-in, not a policy to look up.
House Manual content that assumes the guest read it before arrival. Each step must be self-contained and comprehensible at the moment of action.

Co-occupancy information disclosed for the first time at move-in. It must be signified on the listing page and re-confirmed in the House Manual — the guest should never be surprised by someone else in the space.

elements.title: Listing Space Composition Signifier: Room Type, Bathroom, and Co-Occupancy as Primary Descriptors
elements.problem: Susan's first three questions in the call are: 'Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom?' (0:43), 'What about a bathroom?' (1:08), and 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20). These three questions — space type, bathroom privacy, and co-occupancy — constitute the guest's primary decision variables for shared housing. Yet conventional listing information architecture leads with photos, price, and location. For a platform where many listings involve shared spaces, the guest's first question is not 'Where is it?' or 'How much?' but 'What am I sharing and with whom?' Norman's signifier principle states that people need 'some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.' The listing card must signify the space composition — what the guest gets exclusively, what is shared, and who else is present — as its primary information layer, before price, location, or amenities.
elements.solution: Restructure listing cards and listing page headers to lead with a space composition signifier: a compact, scannable description of what the guest gets. The format is a three-part label: (1) Space type: 'Private Room' or 'Full Apartment' or 'Shared Room.' (2) Bathroom: 'Private Bath' or 'Shared Bath.' (3) Co-occupancy: 'Host present on weekends' or 'No other occupants' or 'Shared with 1 other guest.' This three-part label appears as the first text element on every listing card in search results and as the subtitle on every listing detail page. It answers Susan's first three questions in a single scan line. On the listing detail page, the space composition section expands to show: which rooms are private, which are shared, when the host or other occupants are present, and how common spaces (kitchen, living room) are used. The pattern is: lead with what the guest is sharing, because that is the primary anxiety in shared housing.

evidence.quote: Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom? ... What about a bathroom? ... Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Susan asks three questions in rapid succession, all about space composition. These are not secondary details — they are the primary decision variables that determine whether the listing is even worth evaluating. The information architecture must surface these answers before any other listing details.

evidence.quote: Signifiers communicate where the action should take place... signifiers must be perceivable, else they fail to function.
evidence.insight: The space composition label is a signifier that communicates what kind of space the listing affords. If this signifier is absent or buried in a details section, the guest must read the full description or call an agent to answer their primary question. The signifier fails if it requires effort to find.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there? ... She is going to be there, but she does, she goes out to go to work.
evidence.insight: Bryant explains that the host (Rita) will be present but goes to work during the day. This temporal co-occupancy pattern — host present on some days, absent on others — is critical information that a simple 'Shared' or 'Private' label cannot convey. The listing needs a co-occupancy schedule signifier: 'Host present weekdays during evenings; out during business hours.'

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device.
evidence.insight: If the listing shows beautiful photos of an empty apartment but the guest arrives to find a host and their belongings everywhere, the system image was incoherent — the photos implied 'full apartment' but the reality is 'shared space.' The space composition signifier prevents this incoherence by setting accurate expectations upfront.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: three-part space composition label (space type + bathroom + co-occupancy) as the first text element on every listing card and page header. Secondary: expanded space details — which rooms are private, which are shared, host/occupant schedule. Tertiary: amenities, features, and house rules that depend on the space composition (e.g., 'shared kitchen: guest shelf in fridge'). The ordering ensures the guest's primary anxiety (what am I sharing?) is answered before secondary evaluation (what features does it have?).
elements.disclosure_pattern: On listing cards in search results: three-part label visible immediately, no tap required ('Private Room · Private Bath · Host present weekends'). On listing detail page: space composition section at the top, before photos or price. On expand: detailed room-by-room breakdown with co-occupancy schedule. This matches Susan's question order: space type (0:43) → bathroom (1:08) → co-occupancy (1:20) — the information reveals in the sequence the guest naturally asks.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Three-part label: maximum 8 words total. Expanded space composition: maximum 5 line items (private bedroom, private/shared bath, kitchen access, common areas, co-occupancy schedule). Co-occupancy schedule: maximum 1 sentence ('Host works 9-5 weekdays; present evenings and weekends'). No ambiguous terms: 'Shared' must always specify with whom and when.
scan_order: Space type: 'Private Room' or 'Full Apartment' (System 1: 'What kind of space is this?', under 1 second)
Bathroom: 'Private Bath' or 'Shared Bath' (System 1: 'Do I have my own bathroom?', 1-2 seconds)
Co-occupancy: 'Host present weekends' or 'No other occupants' (System 1: 'Who else is there?', 2-3 seconds)
Expanded space details: room breakdown, schedule, house rules (System 2: detailed evaluation, 3-6 seconds)
exclude: Listing cards that lead with price or location before space composition. For shared housing, what you share matters more than what you pay until the space type is acceptable.
Co-occupancy information buried in the description paragraph or in house rules. It must be a primary signifier, not a discovery-by-reading detail.
Ambiguous labels like 'Shared Space' without specifying what is shared, with whom, and when. 'Shared' is not a useful signifier; 'Private Room, Shared Kitchen with Host' is.
Photos that imply a different space composition than reality (empty apartment photos when a host lives there). Photo captions must align with the space composition label.
